Brighten Visit Tomorrow
The annual Parents' Day of
the Johns Hopkins University
will be held tomorrow. Parents'
Day is an event intended to
unite parents, students, and faculty in an informal atmosphere.

During the morning, faculty
members and their wives will
host an informal gathering for
coffee and buns. Later, during
the afternoon, there will be a
receiving line with Deans and
Faculty, and a banquet at Levering Hall. Other activities, such
as the snack bar lunch and the
Hopkins-Army lacrosse game will
give the parents some insight
into student life here at the

Trustees Appoint
Wolfe To Board
J. Theodore Wolfe, Chairman
of the Board and Chief Executive
Officer of the Baltimore Gas &
Electric Company, has been
elected a life Trustee of the
Johns Hopkins University, it was
announced by Charles S. Garland, Chairman of the Board of
Trustees.
His appointment will become
effective on July 1. The University Board of Trustees numbers
36 voting members.
Mr. Wolfe has been affiliated
with the Baltimore Gas & Electric Company since 1932, the
year he received his Master of
Business Administration degree
from Harvard University. He began as a methods investigator
and has since served successively
as an assistant in the executive
offices, assistant to the vice- president, Vice President, and Executive Vice President, President,
and Chairman of the Board. He
has been Chief Executive Officer

Booster Club Rally-Mixer
The Booster Club, under the
joint direction of Al Bigley and
Jeff Robinson, has planned one
of the biggest pep rallies in recent years for tonight at 7:15.
The theme of this rally is "Let's
Kick A
" and, in the words
of Bigley, it will be "Something
different and more pleasant than
anything we have done here before."

The festivities will get under
way at 7:30 atop the Hopkins
Bowl, facing 33rd Street, and
immediately before the Keyser
Quadrangle. Here will gather the
cheerleaders, the band, members
of the Booster Club, and, hopefully, a large number of the regular student body. Torches will
be available for all vigilantes.
The procession will go from there

Brian Henderson and Don Steiner have sent this information
home to parents, together with
a list of hotels handy to the campus. If your parents have not
already
made
arrangements,
tickets may be purchased from
the Parents' Day committee at a
cost of $4.00 per person.
Sponsored jointly by the Student Council and the Y.M.C.A.,
Parents' Day has been established as an important annual
affair and each year sees the
advent of improvements and increasing successes. By all advance indications this Parents'
Day should continue this tradition by boasting the greatest
success of all.

Smith,Clock Named Business Managers
At a meeting of the staff of
the News-Letter Monday, April
23, Ken Nobel and Ed Morse
were elected editors-in-chief for
the coming year, Tom Smith
and Jack Glock were elected cobusiness managers.

Reinhold step down to graduate.
Promotions

while Morse moves up from managing editor. Smith headed the
composition room staff last year,
while Glock was assistant business manager for the same
period.

"You wouldn't believe homicidal mania could be such fun,"
stated one critic after attending

and Old Lace; but throughout
the years the delicately morbid
plot of Arsenic, has never failed

more amusing, than two old

their
wholesome
hobby of poisoning homeless old
men, don't you agree?

duction which the Barnstormers

Freshmen
Two freshmen were elected to
board of control positions also.
Gary Moore, the assistant news
editor of the outgoing staff, is
now news editor while Jerry Verlin has been selected as copy
editor.
The board of control position
of photography editor is now unfilled. Applicants for that position will be reviewed next year.
The associate staff was partially
selected this week. Thus far,
Dennis Dundas. Ken Lasson and
Howard Maniloff have been
chosen for the news, arts and
sports assistantships.

Hooper Girls
To Sell Souls
For Curfews
Those dear little girls in
Hooper have done it again!
Banding together for the benefit
of the Society for the Prevention of 1:30 A.M.'s, this Mary
Fisher Dorm is sponsoring a car
wash on Tuesday, May 1. After
suffering from the confines of
the 1:30 curfew for years, these
instigators of feminine freedom
have decided to do something
about the chronic late night congestion. Believing that a 3 A.M.
check-in would reduce the acute
traffic problem caused by the
1:30's, the society has been
formed to get the rules changed.
They plan to use the proceeds
of their car wash to bribe the
adMinistration.
They have selected Tuesday,
May 1, as "Ban the Curfew Car
Wash Day." Suitably attired in
washing costumes such as bikini's, they will rub and scrub
in the Mary Fisher parking lot
from 10a.m.-4 p.m. All true Hopkins gentlemen are invited to
lend support to this most worthy
drive to abolish the 1:30 curfew.

A Thorn Among Roses
The schedule of courses for next year, while a great
improvement over Miss Davis' debacle last semester,
leaves something to be desired in the always weak department of consideration for the undergraduate.
Why, for instance, are there only four courses beyond the survey in the Department of English? A paucity
of courses in such a popular area is inexcusable. Admittedly the department is small and great demands are
made on the professors but why, in view of an obvious
manpower shortage, is it necessary for such excellent
teachers as Drs. Wasserman and Miller to give survey
courses? Since most of the real teaching is done in section anyway would it not he wiser to have lectures read
by graduate students anti free the professors to give more
advanced courses?
A different state of affairs prevails in the Department of Romance Languages where most of the hest men
do not see fit to teach undergraduates at all if it can
possibly he avoided. Drs. Girard and Edelman, both
widely regarded in their fields, are virtually unknown to
the average undergraduate. Surely they could he prevailed upon to present at least one non-specialized course
for undergraduates who are interested in the literature
of the periods but lack the proficiency to study it in the
original.
Such neglect is not, fortunately, universal. The offerings in history and philosophy are vastly improved in
variety anti promise to be 80 in content. The science selections are, as usual, excellent. But by failing in two
such basic areas to adequately bridge the gap between
introductory courses and specialized ones, Hopkins fails
in the realm where it is justifiably proudest of its record;
it fails to provide its students with a real basis for independent, informed intellectual endeavor.

they just weren't receptive."

Kudos To Wickwire
Dr. Wickwire has scored again in his consistently
successful effort to bring culture to Homewood. The
standing room only Joan Baez concert was zealously
received by the campus community and proves that
students can he roused from their ghouling, if presented
with appropriate enticement.
We not only offer News-Letter kudos to Wickwire
and his staff, but hope he will he encouraged enough by
the reception of Y sponsored events this year to expand
Lev ering's services to cultural and social areas. Perhaps
a well planned 'big weekend' on Wickwire's part along
with university support and underwriting would lift
more of the University out of the doldrums.

Thanks—
To the Editors:
On behalf of the Johns Hopkins Lacrosse team I would like
to express our appreciation to
the many loyal fans who traveled
down to Charlottesville and
cheered an underdog Hopkins
team to victory over the highly
regarded University of Virginia.
Speaking for myself, I can
truthfully say that it really
sounded great and made me pla,y
all the harder when we were
losing by one goal and the cry
"go Jays" came echoing out of
the stands. It was really a wonderful sound.
I am sure many people are
aware of the test that we are to
meet this Saturday. The Army

team will be twice as tough as
Virginia and it will take a tremendous performance to beat
them, but one of which we are
quite capable. This week we want
to have everyone on the Homewood campus out at the game
and help us take one more step
in the direction of the national
championship.
Phil Sutley
Co-captain
1962 J.H.U. Lacrosse Team

CRAM COURSE NO. 4: BATHYMETRY
Continuing our series of pre-final exam cram courses, today we
take up bathymetry —the study of ocean depths.
Admittedly, this is not a terribly popular course on most
campuses. And small wonder. In the whole world there is only
one bathyscape, and only two people can get into it.
Nevertheless, the study of ocean depths is of great importance. Why,do you realize that the ocean is by far the world's
largest biological environment? The ocean has more than three
hundred times as much living room as all the continents and
islands combined! Unfortunately, only fishes live in it.
And small wonder. Who'd want to live some place where he
couldn't smoke? Surely not 1! I wouldn't give up my good
Marlboro Cigarettes for the Atlantic and the Pacific put together. Nothing could induce me to forego Marlboro's fine
mellow flavor, Marlboro's clean white filter, Marlboro's flip-top
box that really flips, Marlboro's soft pack that's really soft.
Let others repair to the spacious deeps. Me, I will stick with
my Marlboros and the tiny garret I share with a tympanist.
But I digress. Back to the oceans. The largest, as we know,
is the Pacific, which was discovered by Balboa, a Spaniard of
great vision. To give you an idea of Balboa's vision, he first
saw the Pacific while standing on a peak in Darien, which is
in Connecticut.
Even more astounding, when Balboa reached San Francisco,
he clearly saw the Hawaiian Islands! Being, as we know, a
friendly cuss, Balboa waved merrily to the Hawaiians and
shouted,"Great little ocean you got here, kids!" The Hawaiians,
also, as we know, friendly cusses, waved back, declared a half
holiday, organized a luau, built a cheery fire over which they
prepared several gallons of poi, a suckling pig, and Captain
Cook. This, of course, was the origin of Cooking.

But I digress. The Pacific, I say, is the largest ocean and also
the deepest.The Mindanao Trench,off the Philippines, measures
more than 5,000 fathoms in depth. (It should be pointed out
here that ocean depths are measured in fathoms—lengths of
six feet—after Sir Walter Fathom, a noted British sea measurer
of the seventeenth century who, upon his twenty-first birthday,
was given a string six feet long with which he used to go
scampering all over England measuring sea water until he was
arrested for loitering. A passion for measuring seems to have
run in the family; Fathom's cousin, Sir Sol Furlong, spent all
his waking hours measuring race tracks until Charles II had
him beheaded in honor of the opening of the London School of
Economics.)
But I digress, Let us, as the poet Masefield said, go down to
the seas again. (The seas, incidentally, have ever been a favorite
subject for poets and composers.) Who does not remember
Tennyson's "Break, break, break"? Or Byron's "Roll on, thou
dark and deep blue ocean,roll"? Or the many hearty sea chanties
that have enriched our folk music—songs like "Sailing Through
Kansas" and "I'll Swab Your Deck If You'll Swab Mine" and
"The Artificial Respiration Polka." My own favorite sea chanty
goes like this:
A girl loved a sailor and he did jilt her,
And she did weep and roar-ho!
Until she found a perfect filter,
Aild a perfect smoke—Marlboro!
Sing hey, sing ho, sing ring-a-ding-ding,
Sing tars and spars and patches,
Sing pack and box and lots to like,
And don't forget the pnokhes!

Prof. Long Demands
Probe Of Gov't Waste
Dr. Clarence D. Long, Political Economy Professor and a
candidate for Congress, has called for a full-scale investigation
into government waste expenditures. In a companion statement, Dr. Long came out in opposition to income tax deductions of $1,000 campaign contributions but favored the public
disclosure of gifts one week before the election.
Dr. Long took a strong stand
against all government waste.
"Waste exists in all forms of
organization, including business
and family, but waste in government is a particular problem because administrators in government do not have adequate incentive to improve efficiency. In
fact, our civil service system puts
a premium on waste, duplication,
and overlapping. If bureau heads
were promoted or their salaries
raised for reducing their budgets
and staffs, you would see a world
of difference. That's just human
nature."
The noted labor economist
supported some minor income
tax deduction, perhaps up to
$100, because that would encourage more idealistic giving by
moderate income people but the
proposed exemption up to $1,000
would have unfortunate results,
namely
increased
campaign
spending and the creating of a
monopoly of rich candidates
with rich friends.

Hooper Girls
To Sell Souls
For Curfews
Those dear little girls in
Hooper have done it again!
Banding together for the benefit
of the Society for the Prevention of 1:30 A.M.'s, this Mary
Fisher Dorm is sponsoring a car
wash on Tuesday, May 1. After
suffering from the confines of
the 1:30 curfew for years, these
instigators of feminine freedom
have decided to do something
about the chronic late night congestion. Believing that a 3 A.M.
check-in would reduce the acute
traffic problem caused by the
1:30's, the society has been
formed to get the rules changed.
They plan to use the proceeds
of their car wash to bribe the
adMinistration.
They have selected Tuesday,
May 1, as "Ban the Curfew Car
Wash Day." Suitably attired in
washing costumes such as bikini's, they will rub and scrub
in the Mary Fisher parking lot
from 10a.m.-4 p.m. All true Hopkins gentlemen are invited to
lend support to this most worthy
drive to abolish the 1:30 curfew.

A Thorn Among Roses
The schedule of courses for next year, while a great
improvement over Miss Davis' debacle last semester,
leaves something to be desired in the always weak department of consideration for the undergraduate.
Why, for instance, are there only four courses beyond the survey in the Department of English? A paucity
of courses in such a popular area is inexcusable. Admittedly the department is small and great demands are
made on the professors but why, in view of an obvious
manpower shortage, is it necessary for such excellent
teachers as Drs. Wasserman and Miller to give survey
courses? Since most of the real teaching is done in section anyway would it not he wiser to have lectures read
by graduate students anti free the professors to give more
advanced courses?
A different state of affairs prevails in the Department of Romance Languages where most of the hest men
do not see fit to teach undergraduates at all if it can
possibly he avoided. Drs. Girard and Edelman, both
widely regarded in their fields, are virtually unknown to
the average undergraduate. Surely they could he prevailed upon to present at least one non-specialized course
for undergraduates who are interested in the literature
of the periods but lack the proficiency to study it in the
original.
Such neglect is not, fortunately, universal. The offerings in history and philosophy are vastly improved in
variety anti promise to be 80 in content. The science selections are, as usual, excellent. But by failing in two
such basic areas to adequately bridge the gap between
introductory courses and specialized ones, Hopkins fails
in the realm where it is justifiably proudest of its record;
it fails to provide its students with a real basis for independent, informed intellectual endeavor.

CRAM COURSE NO. 4: BATHYMETRY
Continuing our series of pre-final exam cram courses, today we
take up bathymetry —the study of ocean depths.
Admittedly, this is not a terribly popular course on most
campuses. And small wonder. In the whole world there is only
one bathyscape, and only two people can get into it.
Nevertheless, the study of ocean depths is of great importance. Why,do you realize that the ocean is by far the world's
largest biological environment? The ocean has more than three
hundred times as much living room as all the continents and
islands combined! Unfortunately, only fishes live in it.
And small wonder. Who'd want to live some place where he
couldn't smoke? Surely not 1! I wouldn't give up my good
Marlboro Cigarettes for the Atlantic and the Pacific put together. Nothing could induce me to forego Marlboro's fine
mellow flavor, Marlboro's clean white filter, Marlboro's flip-top
box that really flips, Marlboro's soft pack that's really soft.
Let others repair to the spacious deeps. Me, I will stick with
my Marlboros and the tiny garret I share with a tympanist.
But I digress. Back to the oceans. The largest, as we know,
is the Pacific, which was discovered by Balboa, a Spaniard of
great vision. To give you an idea of Balboa's vision, he first
saw the Pacific while standing on a peak in Darien, which is
in Connecticut.
Even more astounding, when Balboa reached San Francisco,
he clearly saw the Hawaiian Islands! Being, as we know, a
friendly cuss, Balboa waved merrily to the Hawaiians and
shouted,"Great little ocean you got here, kids!" The Hawaiians,
also, as we know, friendly cusses, waved back, declared a half
holiday, organized a luau, built a cheery fire over which they
prepared several gallons of poi, a suckling pig, and Captain
Cook. This, of course, was the origin of Cooking.

But I digress. The Pacific, I say, is the largest ocean and also
the deepest.The Mindanao Trench,off the Philippines, measures
more than 5,000 fathoms in depth. (It should be pointed out
here that ocean depths are measured in fathoms—lengths of
six feet—after Sir Walter Fathom, a noted British sea measurer
of the seventeenth century who, upon his twenty-first birthday,
was given a string six feet long with which he used to go
scampering all over England measuring sea water until he was
arrested for loitering. A passion for measuring seems to have
run in the family; Fathom's cousin, Sir Sol Furlong, spent all
his waking hours measuring race tracks until Charles II had
him beheaded in honor of the opening of the London School of
Economics.)
But I digress, Let us, as the poet Masefield said, go down to
the seas again. (The seas, incidentally, have ever been a favorite
subject for poets and composers.) Who does not remember
Tennyson's "Break, break, break"? Or Byron's "Roll on, thou
dark and deep blue ocean,roll"? Or the many hearty sea chanties
that have enriched our folk music—songs like "Sailing Through
Kansas" and "I'll Swab Your Deck If You'll Swab Mine" and
"The Artificial Respiration Polka." My own favorite sea chanty
goes like this:
A girl loved a sailor and he did jilt her,
And she did weep and roar-ho!
Until she found a perfect filter,
Aild a perfect smoke—Marlboro!
Sing hey, sing ho, sing ring-a-ding-ding,
Sing tars and spars and patches,
Sing pack and box and lots to like,
And don't forget the pnokhes!

Drop Opener To

The frosh baseball squad ships
out to Annapolis tomorrow to
take on the Navy Plebes. Coach
Jim Henneman's junior batsmen
lost their opening game Tuesday,
bowing to Glen Burnie, 7-3.
The team played Baltimore
Junior College yesterday afternoon at Homewood.
After Glen Burnie scored once
In the top of the first, the Jays
came back with two after two
were out in their half of the inning to go ahead, 2-1. Geor
ge
Law singled, moving up when
Bob Saie got aboard on an error. Left-fielder John Dalt
on
drove both runners home with
a texas league double to right
center.
Clark Scores
Hopkins increased its margin
by one in the second, when
Jim
Clark walked and came arou
nd
to score on Frank Soria
no's
double. The only other Hopk
ins
batter to hit safely was pinc
hhitter John Ciliberti, who
was
stranded on third after leading
off the seventh inning with with
a booming triple to deep right
center.
In the mean-time, Glen Burn
ie
reached Jay pitchers Mart
y
O'Connell, Dan
Riker, and
Kenny Flowers for seven runs
.
Riker handled the Glen Burnians with dispatch until he
lost
his control in the sixth inni
ng.
Riker had the batters talki
ng
to themselves over his slow stuff
.

against BJC or the men
of
Annapolis. Throwing from
the
left side, Ciliberti packs a good
fastball. His pinch-hit triple
in
the Glen Burnie indicates his
hitting potential.

With an ulcer ridden week of
tennis behind them, the high
flying Hopkins netmen enjoy this
weekend off before traveling to
Western Maryland on Tuesday.
Thursday, April 19, gave little indication of the tennis
matches to come as the Jays
easily swamped Western Maryland 7-2. The Green Terrors
were never in contention as Hopkins swept fur singles and all
three doubles matches.
In perfect tennis weather at
Swarthmore last Saturday, the
netters squeaked by on the good
side of a 5-4 margin. The Garnet,
6-3, gave the Blue Jays some
anxious moments in doubles as
they took all three matches to
three sets after being down 4-2
in singles.
Bob Baron, Burt Schonfeld,
Stu Cameron and Mel Lurie won
in the first four singles by easy
scores. Neal Shepherd lost in
number five while Steve Rothbait went three sets before bowing in the clean up spot. Baron
and Schonfeld were the only
doubles winners as Cameron and
Lurie and Hunter Farnham and
Larry Garceau lost tough matches.

Prof. Long Demands
Probe Of Gov't Waste
Dr. Clarence D. Long, Political Economy Professor and a
candidate for Congress, has called for a full-scale investigation
into government waste expenditures. In a companion statement, Dr. Long came out in opposition to income tax deductions of $1,000 campaign contributions but favored the public
disclosure of gifts one week before the election.
Dr. Long took a strong stand
against all government waste.
"Waste exists in all forms of
organization, including business
and family, but waste in government is a particular problem because administrators in government do not have adequate incentive to improve efficiency. In
fact, our civil service system puts
a premium on waste, duplication,
and overlapping. If bureau heads
were promoted or their salaries
raised for reducing their budgets
and staffs, you would see a world
of difference. That's just human
nature."
The noted labor economist
supported some minor income
tax deduction, perhaps up to
$100, because that would encourage more idealistic giving by
moderate income people but the
proposed exemption up to $1,000
would have unfortunate results,
namely
increased
campaign
spending and the creating of a
monopoly of rich candidates
with rich friends.

Ciccarone Speaks
In connection with this, the
News-Letter
interviewed
cocaptain Henry Ciccarone, who
was asked to express his opinions
on the affair. In essence, he remarked:
"This year the team feels a
greater backing from the student body. The turnout for the
Washington and Lee game was
surprisingly good, and there
have been many listeners to the
WJHU broadcasts, especially the
Virginia game. I feel that a good
pep rally will solidify this support, and give the tea.m an even
greater feeling of student backing."
Not Ten Men
"Well — you like to feel that
you have more than 10 guys out
there playing a game. You would
like to feel, this year especially,
that you have the entire support
of the entire student body —
that each member of the university is on the field with you
playing each play and scoring
each goal. I feel this to be the
most important thing about a
rally. An organized pep rally
conveys the impression that
everyone wants to beat Army,
and is not only looking for a
place to go and drink beer on a
Saturday afternoon."
Bigley, when questioned, emphasized that this rally was attempting to do what Ciccarone
wanted. He thought that this Pep
Rally would be the best ever,
and earnestly requested every
Hopkins man to attend "a real
swingin' evening."
